thread.title_full: Hot Shots: Mike Pedrini a catalyst for Melrose | Boston Herald

author: Dan Ventura
title: Hot Shots: Mike Pedrini a catalyst for Melrose
text:
Melrose football coach Tim Morris says you don’t need a program to know which player he is referring to when describing junior running back Mike Pedrini.
“Mike has great feet, he’s a great athlete who plays every play 100 miles an hour,” Morris said. “If you come to the game, you will notice I am talking about No. 5 pretty quickly out there.”
Pedrini became a household name last year when inserted into the lineup due to injuries. He quickly became one of the guiding forces behind the Red Raiders’ improbable run to the Division 3 championship game at Gillette Stadium.
“The seniors really helped me a great deal,” Pedrini said. “It was a great experience playing with them. They were great leaders and I was glad they were able to get a chance to play at Gillette.”
You spend time with Pedrini and it is clear that the 5-foot-10, 185-pounder is more comfortable talking about the team then himself. Morris says it is one of the qualities which makes Pedrini one of the most popular athletes in the school.
“Mike is a great, great kid,” Morris said. “He’s an outstanding student, has a great work ethic, is consistently in the weight room and always has a smile on his face. He’s definitely the type of kid we want around here.”
With Pedrini around as the lead back this year, Melrose has jumped out to a 4-0 start and leads the Middlesex Freedom. With the veteran group of Jack Hickey, Jake Karelas and Co. gone, Pedrini has seen his role evolve in more ways than one.
“Even though I am playing the same position, my role on the field is growing,” Pedrini said. “I have more responsibilities this year. I’m a year older and I am more confident.”
That confidence shined brightly in last week’s 28-7 over Watertown in a battle of undefeated teams. Pedrini rushed for 166 yards and all four Melrose touchdowns. While the win puts the Red Raiders in the driver’s seat, Pedrini refuses to look too far toward December and a possible second Super Bowl appearance.
“We definitely think about getting back there again,” he said. “But we can’t focus on that. All can we worry about now is Wilmington this week and try to get a good seed in the playoffs.”
